Census Bureau struggles with operational planning for the Decennial Census, as GAO reports highlight recurring cost overruns, with the 2020 Census costing $15.6 billion against initial estimates of $12.5 billion, creating a need for contractors with expertise in cost estimation and risk management tools.

GAO and IG findings note persistent workforce challenges in recruiting and retaining skilled enumerators for field data collection, particularly in hard-to-count areas, requiring contractors to provide scalable training programs and temporary staffing solutions.

Per OMB M-22-09, the Census Bureau must implement Zero Trust Architecture by 2024, but faces gaps in identity management and network segmentation, opening opportunities for contractors offering compliant cybersecurity solutions and integration services.

IG reports identify ongoing issues with data quality assurance in non-decennial surveys like the Current Population Survey, necessitating contractor support for advanced statistical analysis tools and automated data validation processes.

SCALEUP program capacity limitations — evergreen solicitation for commercialization of previous ARPA-E projects cannot fund all promising technologies ready for scale-up
Workforce and program management continuity risk — political leadership changes and budget uncertainty create challenges retaining program directors with deep technical expertise
Technology assessment and milestone tracking burden — quarterly reviews and onsite visits for hundreds of active projects require significant program management overhead
Competing agency missions — overlap with DOE Office of Science, EERE, and new Office of Clean Energy Demonstrations creates confusion about ARPA-E's unique role in the energy R&D ecosystem
Grid reliability and energy security focus shift — pivoting research portfolio toward baseload power and grid reliability may reduce diversity of energy technology exploration
International competition in energy technology — China's massive clean energy R&D spending threatens U.S. leadership in breakthrough energy technologies that ARPA-E aims to maintain
priorities: $414M-$500M FY2026 budget range (Senate plan vs. advocacy target) for breakthrough energy technology R&D across up to 4 new focused solicitations
Grid reliability and baseload power research — technologies supporting firm, dispatchable energy generation and energy storage for grid stability
Nuclear fission and fusion energy R&D — advanced reactor concepts, fusion materials, and nuclear energy technology acceleration programs
Battery and energy storage breakthroughs — next-generation battery chemistries, long-duration storage, and critical materials alternatives
SCALEUP commercialization program — follow-on funding for the most promising ARPA-E project graduates ready to scale from laboratory to commercial deployment
CATALCHEM-E program — future refinery feedstock research including hydrogen, CO2 conversion, sustainable aviation fuel, and syngas-to-distillate technologies
SUPERHOT energy program — advanced geothermal and high-temperature energy extraction technologies for baseload power generation
Critical materials and supply chain research — reducing dependence on foreign-sourced materials for energy technologies and defense applications
Technology-to-Market advisory services — commercialization pathway guidance, milestone tracking, and industry partnership facilitation for funded projects
AI and computational tools for energy R&D — machine learning for materials discovery, energy system optimization, and accelerated technology development cycles

painPoints: Massive budget cut in FY2026 request — Trump administration proposed $888M (74.3% decrease from $3.46B enacted in FY2025); Congress enacted $1.95B net ($3.1B minus $1.15B IIJA transfer)
Solar and wind office funding threatened with elimination — FY2026 administration request proposed zeroing out funding for solar, wind, and hydrogen offices entirely
GAO-25-106748 found DOE Office of Clean Energy Demonstrations needs improved performance management and workforce planning — 101 unfilled positions out of 351 needed as of August 2024
IIJA (Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act) unobligated balance clawback — $1.15B in IIJA appropriations transferred away from EERE programs in FY2026 enacted budget
Clean energy workforce pipeline challenges — insufficient training programs and educational pathways to fill growing demand for solar installers, wind technicians, and EV mechanics
Technology transition from R&D to deployment — moving laboratory innovations through pilot, demonstration, and commercial-scale manufacturing remains a persistent gap
Hydrogen hub implementation delays — Regional Clean Hydrogen Hubs authorized under IIJA face regulatory, permitting, and infrastructure challenges slowing deployment timelines
Vehicle technology electrification timeline pressure — $502M Vehicle Technologies Office budget supporting EV charging infrastructure, battery R&D, and fleet conversion programs
State and local program delivery capacity — distributing billions in formula and competitive grants to entities with varying technical capacity and program management experience
Fossil fuel office budget reductions — even offices focused on fossil fuels and electricity received 30%+ spending cuts, affecting carbon capture and grid modernization research
Bioenergy and sustainable fuels development — $280M Bioenergy Technologies Office advancing sustainable aviation fuel and renewable natural gas against cost competitiveness challenges
Industrial decarbonization complexity — helping heavy industry (steel, cement, chemicals) reduce emissions while maintaining U.S. manufacturing competitiveness
priorities: $1.95B net FY2026 enacted appropriation ($3.1B minus $1.15B IIJA transfer) supporting clean energy R&D, demonstration, and deployment programs across multiple technology offices
$502M Vehicle Technologies Office — electric vehicle charging infrastructure, advanced battery R&D, connected and autonomous vehicles, and fleet electrification programs
$318M Solar Energy Technologies Office — photovoltaics manufacturing, concentrating solar power, systems integration, and solar supply chain resilience
$280M Bioenergy Technologies Office — sustainable aviation fuel, renewable natural gas, algae-based fuels, and waste-to-energy conversion technologies
$199M Wind Energy Technologies Office — offshore wind development, distributed wind, grid integration, and wind manufacturing competitiveness
$179M Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies Office — clean hydrogen production, storage, distribution, and Regional Clean Hydrogen Hub implementation
Water Technology Office (10% budget increase in FY2026) — hydroelectric technology advancement, marine energy development, and enhanced hydropower project optimization
$5M renewable natural gas and clean hydrogen R&D — production technologies, infrastructure, and end-use applications for decarbonized fuel pathways
Advanced Materials and Manufacturing Technologies Office — energy-efficient manufacturing processes, critical materials alternatives, and industrial competitiveness
Building Technologies Office — energy codes, appliance standards, building envelope improvements, HVAC efficiency, and smart building energy management systems

painPoints: Total Hanford cleanup cost estimated at $364B-$589B through 2086 — the most expensive environmental remediation project in world history with costs repeatedly revised upward
Workforce crisis — 263 vacant positions as of end of FY2023, 18% vacancy rate in 14 mission-critical job series, and 44% of staff eligible for retirement by 2030

GAO-24-106479 found 'changes needed to address current and growing shortages in mission-critical positions' — workforce failures have caused project schedule delays, cost overruns, and workplace accidents
Waste disposal capacity shortage — transuranic waste has only one disposal option (WIPP in New Mexico) with limited capacity; high-level waste and spent nuclear fuel have NO disposal site at all
Vitrification plant (WTP) at Hanford cost $17B-$20B and took decades to begin operations — finally started nuclear vitrification in October 2025 but treating 54 million gallons will take decades more
GAO found DOE lacks clear cost and timeline estimates for nuclear cleanups — environmental liability continues to grow with significant management challenges across all cleanup sites
Savannah River Site tank waste treatment — largest remaining environmental risk requires continued operational improvements within waste treatment facilities over the next decade
Idaho National Laboratory waste treatment and disposal challenges — aging waste containers require accelerated processing before containment failures create emergency situations
Stakeholder engagement gaps — GAO-24-106014 found DOE needs to adopt leading practices for engaging with stakeholders and state/tribal/local governments affected by cleanup activities
Environmental liability growth trajectory — EM's total lifecycle environmental liability increases each year as cost estimates are revised and new contamination is characterized
Worker safety at contaminated sites — handling highly radioactive materials in aging facilities with known structural deficiencies creates ongoing occupational health and safety risks
Regulatory compliance pressure — consent agreements with state regulators set enforceable cleanup milestones with financial penalties for missed deadlines
priorities: $3.2B+ for Hanford Site in FY2026 (record budget) — vitrification plant operations, tank waste treatment, groundwater remediation, and facility demolition ($200M increase over previous years)
Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plant (WTP) operations — vitrifying 54 million gallons of radioactive tank waste into stable glass form at $17B-$20B total plant cost
Savannah River Site cleanup — radioactive tank waste treatment, plutonium disposition, tritium operations, and environmental remediation across 310-square-mile nuclear complex
Idaho Cleanup Project — transuranic waste processing, spent nuclear fuel management, aging waste container replacement, and Idaho Waste Treatment Unit operations
Waste Isolation Pilot Plant (WIPP) in New Mexico — transuranic waste disposal operations, capacity expansion, and ventilation system upgrades for the nation's only deep geologic repository
Workforce recruitment and retention — filling 263+ vacant positions in mission-critical job series including nuclear engineers, health physicists, project managers, and safety professionals
Groundwater remediation across EM sites — pump-and-treat systems, permeable reactive barriers, and monitored natural attenuation for contaminated aquifers
Facility decommissioning and demolition — dismantling hundreds of contaminated buildings at Hanford, Savannah River, Oak Ridge, and other former weapons production sites
Radioactive capsule transfer to dry storage — moving highly radioactive cesium and strontium capsules from underwater basin storage to safe, long-term dry cask storage at Hanford
Environmental monitoring and long-term stewardship — maintaining surveillance, monitoring, and institutional controls at remediated sites through 2100 and beyond

painPoints: Aging hydroelectric and transmission infrastructure — BPA's extensive dam and power line network requires billions in deferred maintenance and modernization as equipment reaches end-of-life
Financial pressure from $5B in planned transmission investments — massive grid modernization spending must be funded through rates while maintaining affordability for public power customers
Surplus renewable energy depressing wholesale prices — California solar oversupply pushes West Coast market prices below BPA's cost of power, threatening revenue projections
Fish and wildlife obligations escalating — declining salmon populations toward extinction drive rising mitigation costs, with court-ordered spill increasing expenses by 2%+ surcharges
Federal Treasury debt burden — legacy debt from three nuclear power plants (only one completed) plus ongoing capital borrowing constrains financial flexibility
Lower Snake River dam removal pressure — environmental advocacy and legal challenges threaten four dams generating significant power, with potential $10B+ replacement cost
Cheap natural gas competition — abundant low-cost natural gas generation erodes BPA's competitive advantage and complicates long-term power marketing strategies
Grid congestion and interconnection queue — over $2B in transmission substation and line projects needed just to reinforce existing system before adding new generation capacity
Climate change impacts on hydrology — changing snowpack, earlier runoff, and extreme drought/flood patterns affect hydropower generation reliability and water management
Rate case complexity — BP-26 rate proceeding establishing FY2026-2028 rates must balance infrastructure investment, debt service, fish obligations, and customer affordability
Grid Access Transformation policy changes — proposed changes to federal transmission system access evaluation and expansion processes create uncertainty for customers and generators
Cybersecurity threats to critical infrastructure — protecting dam control systems, SCADA networks, and 15,000+ circuit miles of transmission from nation-state and criminal cyber attacks
priorities: $5B grid expansion and modernization investment — nearly two dozen projects to upgrade and expand the Pacific Northwest transmission system across 15,000+ circuit miles
$2B+ in transmission substation and line reinforcement projects — infrastructure backbone upgrades needed to maintain reliability and accommodate growing energy demand
13 new transmission expansion projects proposed in 2024 — upgrades to power grid for reliability, renewable energy integration, and load growth across the Pacific Northwest
Fish and wildlife mitigation programs — court-mandated salmon recovery, habitat restoration, hatchery operations, and juvenile fish passage improvements at Columbia River Basin dams
Grid Access Transformation workshops (October 2025 - March 2026) — developing new processes for evaluation and expansion of the Federal Columbia River Transmission System
BP-26 rate proceeding implementation — wholesale power and transmission rate schedules for FY2026-2028 balancing investment needs, debt service, and customer affordability
Energy efficiency programs — regional demand-side management investments to reduce load growth and defer transmission capacity additions
Renewable energy integration — grid upgrades to accommodate wind, solar, and battery storage projects connecting to the federal transmission system
Dam safety and modernization — structural upgrades, spillway improvements, and control system modernization across 31 federal dams in the Columbia River Basin
Cybersecurity and SCADA protection — securing dam control systems, transmission management networks, and operational technology against evolving cyber threats

painPoints: Aging transmission infrastructure across 17,000+ circuit miles and 258 substations — much of the system dates back decades, with equipment degradation causing increased unscheduled outages
Supply chain disruptions delaying critical repairs — transformer and high-voltage equipment lead times of 2-3 years creating grid reliability risks at aging facilities
Changing hydrology reducing hydropower generation — drought conditions across the Western U.S. diminish water flows to hydroelectric dams, reducing available power and revenue
Cybersecurity and physical security threats — SCADA systems, energy management platforms, and remote substations across vast Western territories face growing nation-state and criminal threats
Workforce recruitment and retention in remote locations — hiring skilled lineworkers, engineers, and technicians for positions at remote substations across 15 Western states is increasingly difficult
Rate increase pressure — FY2026 total costs of $45.1B increasing 3% over FY2025 due to labor rate inflation and deferred payment catch-up, squeezing customer affordability
Legacy data acquisition systems require modernization — aging SCADA and energy management platforms need upgrades to improve operational efficiency and integrate new data sources
Wildfire risk to transmission infrastructure — increasing frequency and severity of Western wildfires threatens power lines, substations, and rights-of-way across multiple states
Renewable energy interconnection demand — growing queue of wind, solar, and storage projects seeking transmission interconnection straining WAPA's limited planning and engineering resources
Meter reading accuracy and revenue assurance — budget improvements targeted at more accurate metering to capture all power flows and ensure correct customer billing
Vendor payment timeliness — budget resources needed for timely payments to maintenance contractors and equipment suppliers to maintain reliable service relationships
priorities: $3.25B Transmission Infrastructure Program (TIP) borrowing authority — leveraging federal funds to attract private co-investment for critical transmission and related infrastructure expansion
$8.25B DOE loan availability (shared with Loan Programs Office) for transmission grid enhancement and expansion projects nationwide
$45.1B total FY2026 operating costs — operations, maintenance, principal, interest, and capital improvements across 17,000+ circuit miles and 258 substations in 15 Western states
SCADA and energy management system modernization — upgrading data acquisition, monitoring, and control platforms for improved operational efficiency and cybersecurity
Transmission line and substation maintenance — replacing aging transformers, circuit breakers, insulators, and conductor across the Western interconnection
Cybersecurity infrastructure protection — securing operational technology networks, NERC CIP compliance, intrusion detection, and incident response capabilities for critical electric infrastructure
Fiber optic communications network — deploying fiber along transmission corridors to revolutionize information sharing, system monitoring, and grid management capabilities
Renewable energy integration and interconnection — grid studies, system upgrades, and transmission capacity expansion to accommodate growing wind, solar, and battery storage projects
Wildfire resilience and vegetation management — undergrounding, fire-resistant conductor, right-of-way clearing, and situational awareness systems to protect transmission infrastructure
Workforce development and expansion — recruiting and training lineworkers, substation technicians, engineers, and cybersecurity professionals for positions across the Western territory

painPoints: Electronic Health Record Modernization (EHRM) program has ballooned from $16.1B to an estimated $37-49.8B with only 5 of 170+ sites deployed; Oracle-Cerner system has ~1,800 unresolved complex configuration change requests as of Feb 2025
Only 13% of VA staff using the new EHR believe it makes VA efficient; 58% believe the system increases patient safety risks, per GAO-25-108091

VHA facilities reported over 4,400 severe staffing shortages in FY2025 — a 50% increase over the prior year; 94% of facilities report Medical Officer shortages, 79% report Nurse shortages (VA OIG FY2025)
Net loss of 1,720 registered nurses, 600+ physicians, and 80 psychologists in FY2025 alone; up to 37,000 unfilled positions targeted for elimination on top of 30,000 positions already lost
VHA leadership structure described as 'riddled with redundancies that slow decision making, sow confusion and create competing priorities' requiring major organizational restructuring
GAO identified 16 of 18 EHRM recommendations still not fully implemented, with 12 deemed priority recommendations critical to successful future deployments (GAO-26-108812)
Planned 13 simultaneous EHR go-lives in 2026 called 'very risky' by GAO director, requiring unsustainable resource commitments across multiple sites
Aging facility infrastructure with $500M needed annually for major building upgrades (elevators, electrical systems, boiler plants) and another $500M for medical center modernization
Community care referral backlogs and scheduling inefficiencies persist; veterans face long wait times despite billions spent on community care network contracts
Cybersecurity vulnerabilities across 1,300+ facilities with legacy IT systems; Zero Trust Architecture implementation requires $97M increase in FY2026
Mental health and suicide prevention capacity gaps with psychology staffing shortages at 57% of facilities despite veteran suicide remaining a national crisis
Supply chain management weaknesses exposed during COVID continue; medical supply procurement systems remain fragmented across VISNs
priorities: Electronic Health Record Modernization: $3.6B requested for FY2026 (up $2.2B) to support 13 planned site deployments including site readiness, training, and post-go-live support

PACT Act toxic exposure healthcare: Expanded eligibility for 3.5M+ veterans with burn pit and Agent Orange exposure requiring new clinical capacity and screening programs
Medical supply chain and logistics modernization: Enterprise-wide procurement systems to replace fragmented VISN-level purchasing

painPoints: Disability rating schedule criteria are outdated — VA extended timeline to complete comprehensive updates to FY2026, more than 10 years beyond the initial goal (GAO-26-108789)
Claims backlog persists despite record processing: 2.5M+ claims completed in 2024 but PACT Act toxic exposure claims continue to drive volume higher with complex multi-condition evaluations

Digital GI Bill modernization plagued by implementation delays; tens of thousands of students experienced delayed DEA payments due to antiquated Benefits Delivery Network (Nov 2025)

Overdevelopment of claims — excessive and unnecessary evidence requests extend processing times and burden veterans with redundant documentation requirements

priorities: Claims automation and AI: $39M for Decision Intelligence and AI tools including automated decision support, automated review summary documents, and Express 30 Claims Pilot

Home loan program technology: Modernizing VA home loan guaranty systems serving 4.4M+ active loans with $1.2T+ in outstanding guarantees

painPoints: Aging pipeline infrastructure: Over 2.7M miles of pipelines nationwide with significant portions built before modern safety standards; corrosion and material degradation create ongoing failure risks
Hydrogen pipeline safety knowledge gaps: 12 active hydrogen projects totaling ~$11M in research, but regulatory framework lags behind rapid industry growth in hydrogen transport infrastructure
LNG facility expansion outpacing oversight capacity: 8 existing export terminals plus 17 new facilities expected within five years and 7 more seeking approval, straining PHMSA inspection resources

Open NTSB and DOT IG safety recommendations: December 2024 status report shows multiple unresolved recommendations requiring regulatory action and program improvements

Legacy IT systems being consolidated: PHMSA reduced or eliminated nearly two dozen disparate software systems but integration and data migration risks remain during transition
Natural gas distribution system modernization gap: $1B NGDISM grant program (5-year, $200M/year) covers only a fraction of needed replacements for aging cast iron and bare steel pipes

Inspector workforce capacity: iPads and digital tools improve efficiency but total inspector headcount insufficient for expanding pipeline miles and new energy infrastructure

Community pipeline safety outreach: Public awareness programs for pipeline damage prevention, 811 Call Before You Dig, and emergency preparedness

painPoints: Fatal crashes involving trucks 10,001-14,000 lbs increased 44% from 2021-2022; commercial vehicle crashes remain one of the most serious national safety challenges
Fraudulent CDL training programs proliferating: Renewed crackdown needed as entry-level driver training standards face enforcement gaps across states
Drug and Alcohol Clearinghouse compliance gaps: As of 2024, over 200,000 CDL holders had unresolved substance abuse violations but continued operating
Decades-old registration IT infrastructure: FMCSA's Motus platform replacement launched December 2025 but full migration from legacy systems ongoing through 2026
Automatic Emergency Braking mandate delayed: Joint FMCSA/NHTSA rule requiring AEB on new Class 7-8 trucks pushed to 2027, leaving current fleet without safety technology
New entrant safety assurance process outdated: Rulemaking delayed to May 2026; inadequate vetting of new motor carriers enables unsafe operators to enter the industry
Electronic Logging Device compliance and evasion: ELD revision rulemaking scheduled for 2026 to address device tampering, Hours of Service circumvention, and data integrity issues
Side underride guard requirement repeatedly delayed: NHTSA consideration pushed to at least January 2026, leaving trailer-car crash fatalities preventable with known technology
Safety fitness procedures overhaul needed: Current system relies on outdated methodology for rating carrier safety fitness; modernization rulemaking scheduled for May 2026
Truck parking shortage contributing to fatigue-related crashes: $200M proposed for parking expansion but demand far exceeds available safe parking nationwide
priorities: Motor carrier safety operations: $927M total FMCSA funding proposed for FY2026 covering enforcement, technology, and safety programs

Motus registration platform deployment: Full migration to modern, mobile-compatible carrier registration system replacing decades-old infrastructure throughout 2026

Data-driven safety analysis and targeting: IT modernization for crash data systems, Compliance Safety Accountability (CSA) methodology updates, and predictive analytics
Hours of Service and ELD enforcement: Technology upgrades for detecting ELD tampering and HOS violations during roadside inspections

Retirement cliff: Retirement-eligible staff projected to increase from 24% in 2024 to 43% by 2029, threatening institutional knowledge and operational continuity

painPoints: Grade crossing safety remains critical: Over 2,100 highway-rail crossing incidents annually; FRA awarded $1.1B in Railroad Crossing Elimination grants for 1,000+ crossings — the largest single investment in history

Aging rail infrastructure: Tens of billions in deferred maintenance across the national rail network; bridges, tunnels, and track require wholesale replacement in critical corridors

Positive Train Control maintenance and expansion: PTC implementation complete on required lines but ongoing system reliability, interoperability between railroads, and maintenance costs strain resources
Trespasser fatalities account for largest share of rail deaths: Public education and trespass prevention programs insufficient to address ~500+ annual trespasser fatalities
Climate and weather impacts on rail operations: Extreme heat causing rail buckling, flooding washing out track beds, and wildfire threats to infrastructure require adaptation investments
Freight railroad workforce disputes: Crew size requirements, fatigue management, and work-rest scheduling remain contentious safety issues between regulators, railroads, and labor
Passenger rail capacity constraints: Amtrak NEC infrastructure bottlenecks (Baltimore/Potomac Tunnel, Hudson River crossing) limit service expansion and reliability
Blocked railroad crossings creating emergency response delays: Extended freight train blocking of grade crossings impeding ambulance, fire, and police access to communities
priorities: Railroad safety operations and oversight: $3.2B total FRA budget request for FY2026 for data-driven safety improvements and rail service investments

High-speed rail corridor development: Planning and environmental review for designated high-speed corridors including California, Texas, and Pacific Northwest
Railroad bridge and tunnel inspection programs: Safety oversight of approximately 100,000 railroad bridges and critical tunnel infrastructure nationwide

painPoints: Offshore wind development frozen: January 2025 Presidential Memorandum prohibits new leasing, permits, or approvals for offshore wind pending review of federal practices, halting 30GW-by-2030 goal
Massive decommissioning liability gap: BOEM holds $3.3B in bonds covering only ~8% of $42.8B in estimated offshore oil and gas decommissioning costs, exposing taxpayers to enormous financial risk
Environmental review bottlenecks: Each offshore wind project requires NEPA review plus ESA, MSA, and other consultations creating multi-year permitting timelines per project
Oil and gas financial assurance reforms stalled: Proposed modernization of bonding requirements to protect taxpayers from decommissioning costs faces industry opposition and regulatory delays
Offshore wind lease sale schedule eliminated: BOEM removed the five-year lease sale publication requirement and biennial update mandate, creating market uncertainty for developers
Atlantic Shores Wind permit voluntarily remanded: EPA Region 2 pulled back a Clean Air Act permit already issued, demonstrating regulatory instability for approved projects
Lease revenue concentration risk: Renewable energy has generated only $473M in total bonus bids vs. $5B annually in oil/gas royalties, creating budget dependency on fossil fuel production
Environmental study program capacity: Managing concurrent environmental reviews for Gulf of Mexico oil/gas, Atlantic wind, Pacific floating wind, and Gulf wind requires expanded scientific staff
Floating offshore wind technology gaps: California programmatic EIS for floating wind (new technology) requires novel environmental analysis with limited operational data for impact assessment
Aging offshore oil and gas infrastructure: Thousands of platforms, wells, and pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico beyond design life requiring decommissioning oversight and safety monitoring
priorities: Conventional energy program management: Oversight of oil, gas, and mineral leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf generating $5B+ in annual royalty revenue
Renewable Energy Program: $52M FY2025 for advancing offshore wind project development, leasing, and environmental review in federal waters
Environmental Studies Program: Scientific research supporting NEPA reviews, species impact assessments, and ecosystem monitoring for all offshore energy activities
Financial assurance modernization: Updating bonding and financial security requirements to close the $39.5B gap between bonds held and total decommissioning liabilities
Offshore wind environmental review completion: Continued processing of 11 approved COP reviews and pending applications despite policy uncertainty
California floating wind programmatic EIS: Final environmental impact statement for novel floating wind technology in Pacific lease areas
Gulf of Mexico lease sales: Continued conventional energy leasing under the National OCS Oil and Gas Leasing Program
Marine minerals program: Sand and gravel resources for coastal restoration, beach nourishment, and infrastructure projects
Data management and IT systems: Modernizing offshore energy data collection, lease management, and public-facing data portals
Interagency coordination: Working with BSEE, NOAA, USFWS, EPA, DOD, and state agencies on permitting and environmental compliance for offshore projects

painPoints: Decommissioning enforcement failure: Over 75% of end-of-lease and idle infrastructure in the Gulf overdue under BSEE deadlines — 2,700+ wells and 500+ platforms past decommissioning requirements (GAO-24-106229)
Administrative enforcement tools ineffective: BSEE rarely issues civil penalty fines or disqualifies noncompliant operators, failing to incentivize timely decommissioning

Offshore pipeline oversight gaps: GAO found BSEE lacks adequate oversight of thousands of miles of active offshore pipelines and has no robust process for ensuring obsolete pipelines on the seafloor meet safety standards

Cybersecurity threats to offshore operational technology: Offshore platforms increasingly using networked industrial control systems vulnerable to cyber attacks; BSEE still developing OT cybersecurity threat detection program
Deepwater complexity outpacing inspector capabilities: Growing number and complexity of deepwater/ultra-deepwater facilities require more inspection hours and specialized technical capabilities
120+ inspectors insufficient for 20,000+ annual inspections at 1,750+ facilities; expanding offshore renewable energy oversight adds new regulatory responsibilities
Post-Deepwater Horizon reforms still incomplete: BSEE has not fully addressed investigative, environmental compliance, and enforcement deficiencies identified after 2010 disaster (GAO-16-245)
Blowout preventer systems compliance: Ongoing regulatory challenges ensuring BOP maintenance, testing, and performance standards across aging offshore drilling fleet
Arctic and frontier area exploration readiness: Insufficient regulatory framework and inspection capacity for operations in extreme environments with limited emergency response infrastructure
Orphaned well decommissioning backlog: Bipartisan Infrastructure Law provided initial funding but total orphaned offshore infrastructure cleanup costs far exceed available resources
priorities: Offshore safety inspection and enforcement: $252.6M total FY2025 budget ($170.4M appropriations + $82.2M offsetting collections) for OCS safety oversight
Risk-based Inspection Program: Tiered inspection approach ensuring statutory requirements met while focusing resources on highest-risk facilities and operations
Cybersecurity integration for OCS operations: Developing offshore operational technology cybersecurity risk profiles and threat detection/mitigation programs with federal partners
Deepwater inspection capability enhancement: Training, equipment, and staffing for inspecting increasingly complex subsea and deepwater production systems
Offshore renewable energy safety oversight: Expanding regulatory framework and inspection capability for offshore wind farms and other renewable energy facilities
Decommissioning enforcement improvements: Strengthened compliance tools and processes to address 2,700+ overdue well plugging and 500+ overdue platform removals
Orphaned well plugging program: Bipartisan Infrastructure Law funding ($3M initial) for decommissioning offshore orphaned infrastructure
Blowout preventer and well control oversight: Continued enforcement of well control regulations and BOP system testing requirements
Environmental compliance monitoring: Offshore discharge monitoring, air quality compliance, and spill prevention/response readiness
Offshore infrastructure data modernization: Digital dashboards, inspection records management, and data analytics for risk-based regulatory oversight

painPoints: Project review delays severely harm applicants: Virginia officials told GAO that OSMRE took over 1,100 days to review one project proposal, tying up $1.6M that could have funded other projects (GAO-24-106680)
AML Fund collected $14.2B since inception but only $6.6B distributed in grants to states and tribes — massive unobligated balance while hazardous sites persist
Staffing insufficient for $11.3B Bipartisan Infrastructure Law grant administration: OSMRE lacks personnel to efficiently process, monitor, and oversee the 15-year AML program
Financial assurance management challenges: $10.2B in bonds held for coal mine reclamation but industry bankruptcies and declining coal demand threaten surety and self-bonding adequacy
GAO found OSMRE data tracking inadequate for the AMLER economic revitalization program: Cannot effectively measure whether projects achieve community development outcomes
Unclear staff roles and insufficient guidance to states and tribes: GAO recommended clarifying OSMRE's role and providing better technical assistance for grant recipients
Coal fee collection authority uncertainty: Despite BIL extension through 2034, fee rates reduced 20% and declining coal production means reduced future revenue
Acid mine drainage treatment requires perpetual funding: Some AML sites need water treatment in perpetuity with no clear long-term financial mechanism
State regulatory program oversight gaps: OSMRE must oversee 24 primacy state programs and 2 tribal programs with varying levels of technical capacity and enforcement rigor
Legacy coal mine hazards remain extensive: Subsidence, open shafts, unstable slopes, abandoned structures, and contaminated water affect communities across 25 states
priorities: Abandoned Mine Land reclamation grants: $175.8M AML Fund appropriation for FY2025 plus ongoing BIL distributions of ~$725M/year over 15 years ($11.3B total)
Environmental Restoration: $145.9M requested for FY2026 for AML cleanup, water quality improvement, and hazard elimination at abandoned coal mines
Regulation and Technology: $128.9M for FY2025 for oversight of active coal mining operations and state/tribal regulatory program support
AML Economic Revitalization (AMLER) grants: $135M for projects converting legacy coal mining sites to productive economic uses including manufacturing and renewable energy
Regulatory grants to states and tribes: $65M annually supporting 24 state and 2 tribal regulatory programs for active coal mine oversight
Bipartisan Infrastructure Law AML program administration: Managing 15-year, $11.3B distribution to eligible states and tribes for health/safety/environmental hazard remediation
Coal community economic development: Transitional assistance for coal-dependent communities through mine land reclamation and redevelopment projects
Acid mine drainage treatment: Long-term water quality remediation at sites with perpetual treatment requirements
AML inventory modernization: $8M from BIL for states and tribes to update abandoned mine land site inventories and hazard assessments
Technical assistance and training: Building state/tribal capacity for grant administration, project management, and environmental monitoring

painPoints: Proposed FY2026 budget cuts of ~$50M (8% reduction to $582.4M) would eliminate 223 FTE positions and reduce inspections by nearly 10,000 compared to FY2024 levels
Susan Harwood Training Grant Program proposed for elimination — removes $11M+ in safety training grants that fund third-party worker education in high-hazard industries
Heat illness prevention rule still not finalized: NPRM published August 2024, hearing concluded July 2025, but no final standard despite heat being leading cause of weather-related worker deaths
State OSHA programs face inspector recruitment crisis: GAO found states cannot fill vacancies due to shortage of qualified candidates, low salaries, and hiring freezes
Workplace violence in healthcare standard relegated to long-term action: No timeline for proposed rule despite healthcare workers facing 5x higher rates of workplace violence than other industries
Enforcement staff decline reduces inspection capacity: Fewer inspectors mean longer intervals between inspections and reduced deterrent effect, especially in small and medium workplaces
53% of Regional Security Officers in state programs don't meet required qualifications: Language and technical shortfalls affect inspection quality and enforcement effectiveness
Electronic recordkeeping and injury reporting modernization incomplete: Phased changes to Hazard Communication Standard and OSHA 300 log reporting still being implemented
Emerging hazard regulation lagging: Warehouse ergonomics, artificial intelligence workplace impacts, and gig economy worker protections lack specific OSHA standards
Silica dust enforcement in construction remains challenging: Despite 2016 rule, compliance rates in small construction operations remain low due to limited outreach capacity
priorities: Safety and health enforcement: $582.4M proposed FY2026 (reduced from $632.3M in FY2025) for 24,929 planned inspections focused on high-hazard industries
Heat injury and illness prevention rulemaking: First-ever federal heat standard covering general industry, construction, maritime, and agriculture sectors
Hazard Communication Standard updates: Phased implementation of revised chemical labeling, safety data sheets, and workplace exposure communication requirements
State Plan program oversight and support: Federal monitoring and technical assistance for 22 state-plan states covering private sector and 6 covering state/local government workers
Compliance assistance and voluntary programs: Consultation services, VPP (Voluntary Protection Programs), and employer outreach for hazard identification and abatement
Whistleblower protection enforcement: Investigation of retaliation complaints under 25+ federal statutes protecting workers who report safety violations
Fall protection and prevention emphasis: Continued National Emphasis Program targeting falls — the #1 cause of construction worker fatalities
Process Safety Management enforcement: Chemical facility oversight to prevent catastrophic releases following recent incidents at refineries and chemical plants
Combustible dust and chemical hazards: National Emphasis Programs targeting grain handling, chemical manufacturing, and other high-hazard dust-generating industries
IT modernization for inspection and case management: Upgrading inspector field tools, OSHA Information System (OIS), and data analytics for enforcement targeting

painPoints: Survey response rates in freefall: Current Employment Statistics response rate dropped from ~60% pre-pandemic to below 45%, threatening data accuracy for critical economic indicators
Funding eroded 22% since FY2010 in real terms: FY2025 at $636M represents significant purchasing power loss; FY2026 request of $580M would cut another 11.8% after inflation
Current Population Survey modernization at risk: Without adequate funding, CPS upgrades (internet self-response mode) face delays that could endanger labor market data quality
DOL Inspector General audit launched into BLS data collection challenges: IG examining whether declining response rates compromise accuracy of employment, inflation, and wage statistics
Proposed reorganization under Department of Commerce: FY2026 budget proposes merging BLS with Census Bureau and BEA under economic affairs policy direction, creating institutional uncertainty
Consumer Price Index methodology under political scrutiny: CPI data used to adjust Social Security, tax brackets, and federal benefits faces credibility challenges amid falling survey participation
Producer Price Index sample coverage gaps: Industry sector representation declining as response rates fall, potentially introducing bias into wholesale inflation measurements
Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics survey burden: Employers increasingly refusing to participate in mandatory wage surveys, creating gaps in prevailing wage and labor market data
Staffing reductions threaten statistical program continuity: Potential cuts to field economists and statisticians would reduce BLS capacity to maintain quality across 20+ survey programs
Technology infrastructure aging: Legacy data collection, processing, and dissemination systems require modernization but compete for shrinking budget with core survey operations
priorities: Core economic indicator programs: Maintaining Consumer Price Index, Producer Price Index, Employment Situation, and Job Openings/Labor Turnover Survey as Principal Federal Economic Indicators
Current Population Survey modernization: Joint BLS-Census effort to add internet self-response mode, improve response rates among hard-to-reach populations, and update questionnaire design
Labor Force Statistics production: Employment, unemployment, labor force participation, and demographic labor market data used for policy decisions and economic analysis
Prices and Cost of Living programs: CPI, PPI, Import/Export Price Indexes, and Employment Cost Index measuring inflation across consumer, producer, and international markets
Occupational Employment and Wage Statistics: Industry and occupational wage data supporting Davis-Bacon prevailing wage determinations and labor market analysis
Occupational Safety and Health Statistics: Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries and Survey of Occupational Injuries and Illnesses providing workplace safety data
Productivity and Technology research: Measuring labor productivity, multifactor productivity, and unit labor costs across major economic sectors
Data dissemination modernization: Upgrading bls.gov data tools, API services, and public data access platforms for economic researchers, policymakers, and the public
Survey methodology research: Developing techniques to improve response rates, reduce nonresponse bias, and maintain data quality with declining survey participation
Green jobs and emerging economy measurement: Tracking employment in clean energy, AI, remote work, and other evolving economic sectors

painPoints: Unemployment Insurance on GAO High-Risk List since June 2022: System design, infrastructure, and integrity risks threaten billions in benefit payments and program credibility
UI improper payment rate exceeded 18.9% ($78.1B) in FY2021 — DOL failed to meet the statutory requirement of keeping improper payments below 10%
State UI IT systems catastrophically outdated: States with legacy systems started pandemic unemployment programs 8-15 days slower than modernized states (DOL OIG)
Job Corps program proposed for elimination in FY2026 budget: $1.8B program serving 50,000+ at-risk youth at 121 centers faces orderly shutdown under current budget proposal
Community Service Employment for Older Americans (CSEOA) program proposed for elimination: Senior community service employment defunded in FY2026 request
WIOA reauthorization expired and still not renewed: Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act authorization lapsed, creating funding uncertainty for state workforce development systems
UI fraud prevention infrastructure inadequate: Identity verification, cross-state matching, and organized crime detection capabilities lag behind sophisticated fraud schemes
$1B American Rescue Plan UI modernization funding implementation gaps: State adoption of fraud prevention technology and system upgrades proceeding unevenly
Apprenticeship program coordination fragmented: Registered apprenticeship, industry-recognized apprenticeship, and state apprenticeship agency programs lack unified federal oversight framework
Workforce development outcomes tracking insufficient: Limited data on long-term employment outcomes, wage progression, and career pathway completion for WIOA participants
priorities: Unemployment Insurance State Administration: $2.76B for FY2026 (level with FY2025) for state UI agency operations, claims processing, and benefit payments
UI system modernization and fraud prevention: $1B from American Rescue Plan for state IT upgrades, identity verification, and cross-state fraud detection capabilities
Job Corps operations: $1.8B FY2026 for residential education and career technical training for at-risk youth ages 16-24 (though proposed for elimination)
WIOA Adult and Dislocated Worker programs: Formula grants to states for job search assistance, career counseling, and occupational training through American Job Centers
WIOA Youth programs: $948M in FY2025 state allotments for employment, education, and training activities for eligible youth with barriers to employment
Workforce Pell Grant expansion: Implementation support for July 2026 launch of Pell Grant eligibility for short-term workforce training programs
Registered Apprenticeship expansion: Federal support for employer-driven, earn-and-learn training models across construction, healthcare, IT, and advanced manufacturing
Trade Adjustment Assistance: Retraining and income support for workers displaced by foreign trade, including technology-driven job displacement
Indian and Native American Programs (WIOA Section 166): $60M for comprehensive employment and training services to Native American and tribal communities
Reentry Employment Opportunities: Programs connecting formerly incarcerated individuals with job training, career pathways, and employer partnerships

painPoints: Respirable crystalline silica rule implementation in limbo: MNM mines face April 2026 compliance date but MSHA announced limited rulemaking to reconsider portions of the rule, creating regulatory uncertainty
Coal mine silica enforcement delayed: Despite final rule publication in April 2024, coal mine implementation faces continued litigation and potential revision under current administration
Proposed FY2026 budget cuts of ~$14M (10% reduction): House bill would reduce enforcement funding from $266.5M and educational policy from $39M, threatening inspection capacity
Diesel particulate matter exposure in underground mines remains hazardous: DPM concentrations can be 100x higher than surface levels, but transition to electric equipment is slow and costly
Critical mineral mining expansion outpacing safety oversight: Lithium, cobalt, and rare earth mining growth requires MSHA to develop expertise in novel extraction methods and associated hazards
Aging underground mining infrastructure: Ventilation systems, ground control structures, and electrical systems in older mines require continuous monitoring and upgraded safety standards
Mining fatality trends in metal/nonmetal sector: While coal mining fatalities have decreased, MNM sector incidents remain stubbornly persistent, particularly in quarries and sand/gravel operations

Inspector training gaps for emerging technologies: Autonomous mining equipment, remote-controlled machinery, and AI-powered monitoring systems create new safety paradigms MSHA inspectors lack training for
Small mine compliance assistance insufficient: 12,000+ active mines, many small operations with limited safety resources, need expanded outreach but face reduced educational funding
Powered haulage incidents remain leading cause of mining deaths: Trucks, conveyors, and mobile equipment continue causing disproportionate fatalities despite targeted enforcement programs
priorities: Mine safety and health enforcement: $266.5M for FY2025 enforcement operations covering 12,000+ active coal and metal/nonmetal mines
Respirable crystalline silica compliance: Implementation support, monitoring technology, and enforcement for new permissible exposure limits across MNM mines
Educational policy and development: $39M for safety training, technical support, and compliance assistance programs for mine operators and miners
Powered haulage safety emphasis: Targeted inspection programs and enforcement actions addressing the leading cause of mining fatalities
Diesel particulate matter exposure reduction: Promoting transition to Tier 4 diesel engines and battery-electric vehicles in underground mines
Critical mineral mining safety standards: Developing regulatory expertise and inspection protocols for lithium, rare earth, and other critical mineral extraction operations
Ground control and roof fall prevention: Technical support and enforcement for the second-leading cause of underground mining fatalities
Emergency response and mine rescue: Maintaining and training mine rescue teams, updating emergency response plans, and modernizing communication systems
Respirable dust monitoring technology: Deploying continuous personal dust monitors and real-time exposure tracking in coal and MNM mines
Small mine compliance outreach: Targeted education and technical assistance for small mining operations with limited safety management resources

painPoints: 165M+ workers in 11M+ workplaces but enforcement staff has declined for years: Rebuilding investigator workforce is critical for systemic compliance improvement

Davis-Bacon prevailing wage methodology change facing implementation challenges: Return to pre-1983 30% threshold (from 50%) requires resurveying wage rates across all counties and construction trades
Back wage recovery hit 5-year high of $259M in FY2025 for 177,000 employees but represents fraction of actual wage theft: Estimated $15B+ annually in minimum wage violations alone goes unrecovered

H-2A and H-2B temporary worker program oversight strained: Growing agricultural and seasonal worker visa programs require increased investigation capacity for wage, housing, and working condition violations
Misclassification of employees as independent contractors persists: New enforcement guidance issued but gig economy growth outpaces investigative capacity to identify and remedy violations

Prevailing wage enforcement complexity increased by Bipartisan Infrastructure Law: BIL-funded construction projects trigger Davis-Bacon requirements across new categories including energy infrastructure
Cases requiring more investigator hours and expertise produce vastly better outcomes but productivity metrics historically favored case volume over quality, misallocating resources
FLSA overtime rule uncertainty: Federal court actions have blocked or modified overtime threshold updates, creating enforcement complexity and employer confusion
Child labor violations resurging: Significant increase in minors employed in hazardous occupations, particularly in meatpacking, roofing, and overnight cleaning operations
Tip credit, joint employer, and franchise compliance gaps: Complex multi-employer arrangements in food service and hospitality create wage theft patterns difficult to investigate and remediate
priorities: FLSA enforcement operations: Minimum wage, overtime, recordkeeping, and child labor investigations protecting 165M+ workers across the economy
Davis-Bacon and prevailing wage enforcement: Ensuring prevailing wage compliance on federal construction contracts, expanded by BIL infrastructure spending
Investigator workforce rebuilding: Hiring and training wage and hour investigators to restore enforcement capacity after years of staffing decline
H-2A agricultural worker protection: Investigating wage, housing, and working condition compliance for temporary agricultural worker visa programs
H-2B seasonal worker protection: Enforcement of wage and benefit requirements for non-agricultural temporary worker programs
Child labor enforcement priority: Expanded investigations targeting illegal employment of minors in hazardous occupations (meat processing, construction, late-night cleaning)
Misclassification enforcement: Investigating employee-vs-contractor classification violations in gig economy, construction, and service industries
Service Contract Act compliance: Prevailing wage and fringe benefit enforcement for federal service contracts covering janitors, guards, food service workers
Back wage recovery and liquidated damages: Collecting unpaid wages and penalties from violating employers; $259M recovered in FY2025
Outreach and compliance assistance: Employer education, industry-specific compliance guidance, and multilingual worker rights information

painPoints: Embassy construction costs losing purchasing power: $1.1B in purchasing power lost since 2015 in the Capital Security Construction Program despite ~$2B annual funding (GAO-25-107582)

Diplomatic Security grew rapidly without strategic assessment: GAO found growth lacked comprehensive planning, resulting in mismatched domestic-overseas position allocations and resource inefficiencies

53% of Regional Security Officers don't meet required foreign language proficiency levels: Language shortfalls affect diplomatic engagement, intelligence gathering, and local law enforcement coordination
45,870 contract security personnel worldwide create massive contractor management burden: Oversight of guard forces, technical security systems, and construction security across 275+ posts
Many diplomatic residences fail to meet security standards: Physical security upgrades for ambassador and staff residences lag behind embassy compound improvements
Crisis and evacuation preparedness gaps identified: State's implementation and monitoring of emergency evacuation plans could endanger staff and family members at overseas posts
Cybersecurity threats to diplomatic communications: Foreign Affairs Cybersecurity Center faces evolving nation-state and criminal threats targeting classified and unclassified networks
High-hardship post staffing challenges: Difficulty posting fully qualified security personnel to dangerous and remote assignments with limited amenities and elevated threat environments
Proposed 28% cut to State Department budget for FY2026: $8.6B requested for Diplomatic Programs represents $844M (-9%) cut from FY2025, threatening security operations worldwide
Increasing global threat landscape: Embassy security must address terrorism, civil unrest, cyber attacks, insider threats, and surveillance across 275+ diplomatic facilities simultaneously
priorities: Diplomatic Security operations: $3.4B allocated to DS within the Diplomatic Programs account for personnel, infrastructure, and security operations worldwide
Capital Security Construction Program: ~$2B annually for new embassy compound construction; 99 embassies built since 1998 East Africa bombings at ~$40B total program cost
Overseas protective security: Personal protection for diplomats, visiting officials, and foreign dignitaries including motorcade operations and event security
Cybersecurity and information assurance: Foreign Affairs Cybersecurity Center operations protecting diplomatic communications, networks, and classified systems worldwide
Guard force management: Oversight of 45,870+ contract security personnel including local guard programs, Marine Security Guards, and technical surveillance countermeasures
Construction security and technical countermeasures: Securing embassy construction sites and detecting/neutralizing electronic surveillance devices in diplomatic facilities
Counterintelligence and insider threat programs: Protecting against espionage, recruitment of US personnel, and unauthorized disclosure of classified information
Diplomatic courier service: Secure transport of classified materials between Washington and 275+ overseas posts
Threat investigation and analysis: DS field office investigations into passport/visa fraud, identity theft, and crimes against US persons overseas
Emergency action planning and crisis response: Maintaining evacuation plans, crisis communication systems, and emergency response capability for all overseas posts

painPoints: Revenue sustainability at risk: COVID-19 caused 41% decline in consular fee revenue in FY2020; GAO simulation showed projected revenue may not cover costs through FY2026 across multiple recovery scenarios (GAO-22-104424)
Visa processing backlogs persist unevenly: Some consulates cleared backlogs by late 2024, while others estimated 2+ years to schedule all waiting cases — creating inconsistent service worldwide
Passport demand at 'magnitudes above' prior years: 2M+ online renewals processed since September 2024 launch, but staffing and infrastructure must keep pace with explosive growth
Immigrant visa processing suspended for 75 countries effective January 2026: Policy change dramatically reduces consular operations while creating massive future backlogs when processing resumes
Fee-funded operating model vulnerability: Bureau depends almost entirely on passport and visa application fees rather than appropriations, creating boom-bust budget cycles tied to travel demand
Online passport renewal system leader departed July 2025: Key technology leader behind successful digital transformation stepped down, risking momentum on further IT modernization
Fraud detection capabilities require continuous investment: Identity fraud, document forgery, and visa fraud schemes grow more sophisticated, requiring advanced biometric and analytics tools
Mobile app mandate unfulfilled: Department of State Authorization Act requires creation of mobile app for passport applicants to communicate with DOS during adjudication — not yet implemented
Overseas consular staffing shortfalls: Despite 34% increase since January 2022, adjudicative staff levels still insufficient to handle post-pandemic visa demand surge at many posts
American Citizens Services worldwide demand: Assisting US citizens in emergencies, deaths, arrests, and evacuations overseas with finite consular officer resources across 200+ countries
priorities: Consular Affairs total operations: $4.2B FY2026 allocation (increase of $195M from FY2025) for passport, visa, and citizen services worldwide
Consular Systems and Technology: $821M for IT systems supporting passport adjudication, visa processing, fraud detection, and citizen services platforms
Cybersecurity activities: $744M across State Department IT for protecting consular data, biometric systems, and diplomatic communications
Online passport renewal expansion: Broadening eligibility criteria and capabilities of the digital renewal platform processing 50%+ of all renewals
Passport mobile app development: Building mobile application enabling applicants to track status and communicate with DOS during adjudication process
Fraud Prevention and Detection: Dedicated fee-funded activities for biometric verification, document authentication, and identity fraud investigation
Visa processing capacity restoration: Staffing and technology to address post-pandemic backlogs, particularly for immigrant visa categories with multi-year wait times
Passport production and security: Next-generation e-passport issuance with enhanced biometric features and anti-counterfeiting technology
American Citizens Services: Emergency response capability for US citizens abroad including evacuations, welfare/whereabouts checks, and crisis assistance
Consular officer recruitment and training: Expanding adjudicative workforce with 34%+ growth since 2022 and developing expertise in fraud detection and immigration law
